title: Edward B. Quinn, PhD, MPH
text:
I am a Senior Data Analyst and a published health researcher. My PhD training was in epigenetics and health equity, where I used R to analyze over 400 million data points.
My skill set is currently expanding to include Shiny, SQL, Python, Tableau, and PowerBI. In my spare time, I love to travel and watch mixed martial arts.

title: Using Machine Learning to Predict Diabetes
Using Machine Learning to Predict Diabetes
text:
Predicting Diabetes
One of the most exciting applications of machine learning is in the prediction of disease states. Here, I demonstrate the use of the newest modeling framework in R to compare many different types of models in the prediction of diabetes.
The data come from citation and link to full citation footnote.
Let’s load our libraries.

CodesuppressPackageStartupMessages(library(tidyverse))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(tidymodels))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(RCurl))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(GGally))
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(here))


tidymodels_prefer()


Read in the data and take a look at the first ten rows:

Codedf <- read_csv(here("r_projects/r_machine_learning/diabetes.csv"))

df

# A tibble: 768 × 9
   Pregnancies Glucose BloodPressure SkinThickness Insulin   BMI
         <dbl>   <dbl>         <dbl>         <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl>
 1           6     148            72            35       0  33.6
 2           1      85            66            29       0  26.6
 3           8     183            64             0       0  23.3
 4           1      89            66            23      94  28.1
 5           0     137            40            35     168  43.1
 6           5     116            74             0       0  25.6
 7           3      78            50            32      88  31  
 8          10     115             0             0       0  35.3
 9           2     197            70            45     543  30.5
10           8     125            96             0       0   0

It is always a good idea to visualize the data as part of exploratory data analysis.

Code#| message: false

ggplot(df, aes(Age, BMI)) +
  geom_point()
